Transition Vocabs.definition: A person who makes pottery, especially by shaping clay and firing it in a kiln.
Transition Vocabs.example: The local potter sells handmade mugs and bowls at the weekend market.

Transition Vocabs.definition: A hollow container, especially one used to hold liquids or for artistic purposes.
Transition Vocabs.example: The ship was a large vessel carrying cargo across the Atlantic.

Transition Vocabs.definition: To cover or envelop completely, often in order to extinguish or suppress.
Transition Vocabs.example: She tried to smother the fire with a heavy blanket.

Transition Vocabs.definition: A particular color or shade of a color.
Transition Vocabs.example: The sunset painted the sky in a brilliant hue of orange and pink.

Transition Vocabs.definition: To cut or carve a design, pattern, or text into a surface, usually for artistic or recording purposes.
Transition Vocabs.example: The artist etched her initials into the metal plate.

Transition Vocabs.definition: A drawing consisting of lines without shading or coloring, often used to show shape or outline.
Transition Vocabs.example: He created a simple line drawing of the building before adding color.

Transition Vocabs.definition: A long, narrow mark or band, often drawn or visible on a surface.
Transition Vocabs.example: She drew a straight line across the page with her ruler.

Transition Vocabs.definition: A low hill at the base of a mountain or mountain range.
Transition Vocabs.example: They hiked up the foothill to get a better view of the valley below.

Transition Vocabs.definition: A visible sign, symbol, or pattern on a surface, often for identification or decoration.
Transition Vocabs.example: The turtle’s shell had unique markings that made it easy to identify.

Transition Vocabs.definition: Describing an image or display that has a very high level of detail or clarity.
Transition Vocabs.example: The scientist examined high-resolution images of the cells under a microscope.

Transition Vocabs.definition: A principal taxonomic category that ranks above class and below kingdom, used to group organisms with a common basic structure.
Transition Vocabs.example: Humans belong to the phylum Chordata, which includes all animals with a notochord.

Transition Vocabs.definition: A plant that retains green leaves throughout the year instead of shedding them seasonally.
Transition Vocabs.example: Pine trees are evergreen and keep their needles even in winter.

Transition Vocabs.definition: Continuing throughout the entire year; not limited to a specific season.
Transition Vocabs.example: The park is open year-round for visitors to enjoy.

Transition Vocabs.definition: A type of coniferous tree that loses its needles in autumn, unlike most conifers.
Transition Vocabs.example: The larch tree turns golden before shedding its needles in the fall.

Transition Vocabs.definition: A thin, pointed leaf of certain trees, such as pines, spruces, and firs.
Transition Vocabs.example: The pine tree’s needles provide insulation against the cold.

Transition Vocabs.definition: Small, flat structures, often at the tips of hairs or appendages, that help in attachment or spreading.
Transition Vocabs.example: The gecko's spatulae at the tips of its toes allow it to stick to walls.

Transition Vocabs.definition: To hold on tightly to something or stick closely to a surface.
Transition Vocabs.example: The wet shirt clung to her skin after she got caught in the rain.

Transition Vocabs.definition: To exist or live across two different conditions, situations, or places at the same time.
Transition Vocabs.example: She had to straddle two jobs to support her family while continuing her studies.

Transition Vocabs.definition: A recorded account of personal experiences or events told by someone who witnessed or experienced them.
Transition Vocabs.example: The museum collected oral histories from veterans to preserve their stories.

Transition Vocabs.definition: A person or individual being studied, observed, or documented in research.
Transition Vocabs.example: The psychologist interviewed each subject about their daily habits.

Transition Vocabs.definition: To surround, contain, or cover something completely; to include a wide range or area.
Transition Vocabs.example: The national park encompasses forests, lakes, and mountains within its boundaries.

Transition Vocabs.definition: To try to obtain, ask for, or look for something, such as advice, help, or information.
Transition Vocabs.example: She sought guidance from her mentor before making a major career decision.

Transition Vocabs.definition: To make something thinner or narrower in shape or size.
Transition Vocabs.example: The designer slimmed the furniture legs to give the table a more elegant look.

Transition Vocabs.definition: To slant or lean something away from a vertical or horizontal position.
Transition Vocabs.example: He tilted the painting out slightly to reduce glare from the lights.

Transition Vocabs.definition: To cause to slope, slant, or lean in a particular direction.
Transition Vocabs.example: The old bookshelf began to tilt after years of holding heavy books.

Transition Vocabs.definition: A written representation of a musical composition, showing all the parts for performers.
Transition Vocabs.example: The pianist studied the score carefully before the recital.

Transition Vocabs.definition: Instructions in a musical score that guide singers on how to perform certain passages, including style, dynamics, or expression.
Transition Vocabs.example: The conductor gave clear vocal directions to help the choir sing in harmony.

Transition Vocabs.definition: A system of written symbols used to represent music, sounds, or instructions for performance.
Transition Vocabs.example: The composer wrote precise notation to indicate the rhythm and pitch of each instrument.

Transition Vocabs.definition: Representing what is normal or expected in a particular situation.
Transition Vocabs.example: A typical day at school starts with morning announcements.

Transition Vocabs.definition: A person who measures and examines land, structures, or sites to determine boundaries or layout.
Transition Vocabs.example: The surveyor marked the property lines before construction began.

Transition Vocabs.definition: A network of lines that cross each other to form squares, used for measurement or organization.
Transition Vocabs.example: The city streets are laid out in a grid pattern for easy navigation.

Transition Vocabs.definition: To record or assign something onto a specific layout or reference system.
Transition Vocabs.example: The scientist mapped the sample locations onto the chart for analysis.

Student Notes Vocabs.definition: A device for connecting train cars together.
Student Notes Vocabs.example: The engineer replaced the old coupler to ensure the new train cars were securely joined.

Student Notes Vocabs.definition: Likely to decay or go bad quickly, especially food.
Student Notes Vocabs.example: You should store perishable items like milk and cheese in the fridge.

Student Notes Vocabs.definition: Having a strange, dreamlike, or unreal quality.
Student Notes Vocabs.example: The movie’s surreal landscapes made the audience feel as if they were in a dream.

Student Notes Vocabs.definition: To begin to grow or produce shoots or buds.
Student Notes Vocabs.example: After a few days of watering, the seeds started to sprout in the garden.

Student Notes Vocabs.definition: Serving as a symbol or representing something beyond the literal meaning.
Student Notes Vocabs.example: The dove is symbolic of peace in many cultures.

Student Notes Vocabs.definition: A painting, drawing, or photograph of an artist created by the artist themselves.
Student Notes Vocabs.example: The student drew a self-portrait using only pencil and shading techniques.

Student Notes Vocabs.definition: To cause a sudden shock or fear; to surprise.
Student Notes Vocabs.example: The loud clap of thunder startled everyone in the room.

Student Notes Vocabs.definition: Firm, regular, and unchanging in intensity or rate.
Student Notes Vocabs.example: She held the ladder steady while her brother climbed up to fix the roof.

Student Notes Vocabs.definition: Important, well-known, or easily noticed.
Student Notes Vocabs.example: The prominent scientist was invited to speak at the international conference.

Student Notes Vocabs.definition: A person who plays the flute professionally or as a hobby.
Student Notes Vocabs.example: The flutist practiced daily to perfect her performance for the concert.

Student Notes Vocabs.definition: To produce percussion sounds and rhythms using the mouth, lips, tongue, and voice.
Student Notes Vocabs.example: He learned to beatbox by watching online tutorials and practicing every day.

Student Notes Vocabs.definition: Using more than one form of communication or artistic expression, such as text, images, video, and sound.
Student Notes Vocabs.example: The museum hosted a multimedia exhibition featuring paintings, video installations, and sound art.

Student Notes Vocabs.definition: A person who creates art primarily to be seen, including painting, sculpture, photography, and installations.
Student Notes Vocabs.example: As a visual artist, she specializes in creating large-scale murals for public spaces.

Student Notes Vocabs.definition: To join or blend two or more things together to form a single entity.
Student Notes Vocabs.example: The chef decided to fuse traditional Italian flavors with Japanese ingredients in her new dish.

Student Notes Vocabs.definition: The wheel located at the back of a bicycle, vehicle, or machine.
Student Notes Vocabs.example: He replaced the rear wheel of his bicycle after it got damaged during the ride.

Student Notes Vocabs.definition: A soldier who fights on foot, often as part of an army's infantry.
Student Notes Vocabs.example: The infantryman trained for months before being deployed to the front lines.

Student Notes Vocabs.definition: A branch or organized group of people in the military or other organization.
Student Notes Vocabs.example: The army formed a new engineering corps to handle construction and logistics.

Student Notes Vocabs.definition: To perform or act out an event that happened in the past.
Student Notes Vocabs.example: Each year, the community reenacts the historic battle to educate visitors about local history.

Student Notes Vocabs.definition: Sitting or resting on a branch, ledge, or similar elevated spot, as birds often do.
Student Notes Vocabs.example: The sparrow was perching on the windowsill, watching the garden below.

Student Notes Vocabs.definition: Decorative work made with ceramic or stone tiles.
Student Notes Vocabs.example: The mosque's walls were covered in colorful tilework featuring geometric patterns.

Student Notes Vocabs.definition: Very detailed, complicated, and carefully made.
Student Notes Vocabs.example: The intricate carving on the wooden door impressed all visitors.

Student Notes Vocabs.definition: To press a design or pattern into a surface.
Student Notes Vocabs.example: The artisan stamped intricate patterns into the leather to decorate the book cover.

Student Notes Vocabs.definition: To watch over and manage a project, task, or group of people.
Student Notes Vocabs.example: The manager will oversee the new construction project to ensure it stays on schedule.

Student Notes Vocabs.definition: To examine something carefully or to make a digital copy, often using a machine.
Student Notes Vocabs.example: The librarian will scan the old manuscripts to preserve them digitally.

Student Notes Vocabs.definition: Paintings or carvings made on natural rock surfaces, usually by ancient peoples.
Student Notes Vocabs.example: Archaeologists discovered prehistoric rock art depicting hunting scenes in the cave.

Student Notes Vocabs.definition: An initial payment made when purchasing something expensive, with the remaining amount paid later.
Student Notes Vocabs.example: They paid a down payment on the house before taking a loan.

Student Notes Vocabs.definition: Something that does not change or happens all the time.
Student Notes Vocabs.example: There was constant noise coming from the street.

Student Notes Vocabs.definition: To slow down or prevent progress or movement.
Student Notes Vocabs.example: Poor weather conditions can impede travel.

Student Notes Vocabs.definition: To collect or combine resources, money, or efforts together.
Student Notes Vocabs.example: The team pooled their ideas to solve the problem.

Student Notes Vocabs.definition: A rare weather phenomenon where thunder and lightning occur during snowfall.
Student Notes Vocabs.example: The region experienced thundersnow during the winter storm.

Student Notes Vocabs.definition: A part of the brain that relays sensory information to the cerebral cortex.
Student Notes Vocabs.example: The thalamus processes signals related to sight and sound.

Student Notes Vocabs.definition: A group of interconnected neurons that work together to process information.
Student Notes Vocabs.example: Memory formation depends on specific neural circuits.

Student Notes Vocabs.definition: Related to space, position, or physical arrangement.
Student Notes Vocabs.example: The test measured the students’ spatial abilities.

Student Notes Vocabs.definition: A hint or signal that triggers a response or action.
Student Notes Vocabs.example: The teacher gave a verbal cue to start writing.

Student Notes Vocabs.definition: The system of electrical circuits or interconnected pathways in a device or brain.
Student Notes Vocabs.example: The phone stopped working due to damaged circuitry.

Sentence Types.definition: To act in accordance with rules, standards, or expectations.
Sentence Types.example: Writers often conform to grammatical rules to make their work clear and professional.

Sentence Types.definition: An established practice, rule, or standard widely accepted by a group or society.
Sentence Types.example: Using paragraphs to organize ideas is a convention in academic writing.

Sentence Types.definition: The process by which something gradually breaks down or decomposes.
Sentence Types.example: The decay of the old tree made it unsafe to climb.

Sentence Types.definition: High-energy electromagnetic radiation emitted during the decay of radioactive atomic nuclei.
Sentence Types.example: Gamma radiation is used in medical treatments to target cancer cells.

Sentence Types.definition: A new plan or strategy designed to achieve a specific goal.
Sentence Types.example: The government launched an initiative to improve public transportation.

Sentence Types.definition: Carrying too much work, responsibility, or pressure.
Sentence Types.example: The overburdened teachers struggled to grade all the assignments on time.

Sentence Types.definition: A public service such as electricity, water, or gas that is provided for general use.
Sentence Types.example: The city restored the water utility after the storm caused a blackout.

Sentence Types.definition: Housing provided by an organization or company for its workers.
Sentence Types.example: The national park built employee housing to accommodate seasonal rangers.

Sentence Types.definition: A piece of land where fruit trees are cultivated.
Sentence Types.example: The family visited the apple orchard every autumn to pick fresh fruit.

Sentence Types.definition: Able to be used for many different purposes or functions.
Sentence Types.example: Plastic is versatile, as it can be molded into countless shapes and products.

Sentence Types.definition: To break down naturally through the action of bacteria, fungi, or other biological processes.
Sentence Types.example: Some packaging materials can biodegrade within a few months.

Sentence Types.definition: A site for the disposal of waste materials by burial under layers of soil.
Sentence Types.example: Many plastic products end up in landfills where they take hundreds of years to decompose.

Sentence Types.definition: A resource that cannot be replaced or regenerated at the rate it is consumed.
Sentence Types.example: Petroleum is a nonrenewable resource, so it must be used carefully.

Sentence Types.definition: A naturally occurring liquid found beneath the Earth's surface, used as fuel and for making plastics.
Sentence Types.example: Most commercial plastics are made from petroleum.

Sentence Types.definition: A person who works to promote and protect the rights of people with disabilities.
Sentence Types.example: Kitty Cone was a disability rights activist who fought for equal opportunities for all.

Sentence Types.definition: To make an urgent or emotional appeal.
Sentence Types.example: The activists pleaded with lawmakers to pass the antidiscrimination legislation.

Sentence Types.definition: Without producing any result or desired outcome.
Sentence Types.example: They petitioned the government for years, but it was to no effect.

Sentence Types.word: for the passage of key antidiscrimination legislation
Sentence Types.definition: In order to have important laws preventing discrimination approved and enacted.
Sentence Types.example: The group organized campaigns for the passage of key antidiscrimination legislation.

Sentence Types.definition: A person who makes or enacts laws, typically a member of a legislative body.
Sentence Types.example: Lawmakers debated the bill before finally approving it.

Sentence Types.definition: To plan and carry out an event or activity, often publicly.
Sentence Types.example: The activists staged a protest outside the federal building.

Sentence Types.definition: A form of protest in which participants occupy a space and refuse to leave until their demands are met.
Sentence Types.example: The sit-in lasted for several weeks until the legislation was signed.

Sentence Types.definition: A thin strip of material on a wind instrument that vibrates to produce sound.
Sentence Types.example: The musician replaced the old reed on her clarinet to improve the sound.

Sentence Types.definition: The part of a wind instrument that is placed in or near the mouth to produce sound.
Sentence Types.example: He cleaned the mouthpiece of his saxophone before practice.

Sentence Types.definition: The material, usually from a plant, used to make the vibrating strips in wind instruments.
Sentence Types.example: The double reed is made from two pieces of cane that produce a unique sound.

Sentence Types.definition: A philosophical statement by René Descartes asserting that the very act of thinking proves one's existence.
Sentence Types.example: Descartes concluded 'I think, therefore I am' to demonstrate the certainty of his own existence.

Sentence Types.definition: To conceal or cover the true nature of something.
Sentence Types.example: The phrase's simplicity masks its philosophical depth.

Sentence Types.definition: To think about something carefully, especially in depth.
Sentence Types.example: Only those who exist can ponder questions about their own existence.

Joining and Separating.definition: A formal written request signed by many people appealing to authority for a specific cause.
Joining and Separating.example: Students started a petition to have longer library hours during exam week.

Joining and Separating.definition: To shock or surprise someone greatly.
Joining and Separating.example: I was completely taken aback when I saw the stunning view from the mountain top.

Joining and Separating.definition: A visual representation or drawing used to explain or decorate something.
Joining and Separating.example: The book included a beautiful illustration of a medieval castle.

Joining and Separating.definition: Decorated or brightened, often with artistic lighting or designs.
Joining and Separating.example: The cathedral had illuminated manuscripts on display in the gallery.

Joining and Separating.definition: Occurring at the beginning; also, the first letter of a name.
Joining and Separating.example: Her initial reaction was to laugh, but then she realized the seriousness of the situation.

Joining and Separating.definition: A goal or object that someone directs effort or action toward.
Joining and Separating.example: The marketing campaign is designed to target young adults aged 18–25.

Joining and Separating.definition: The precise order of nucleotides in a DNA molecule.
Joining and Separating.example: Researchers analyzed the DNA sequence to determine the origin of the rare plant species.

Joining and Separating.definition: Aware of and responding to one's surroundings; deliberate or intentional.
Joining and Separating.example: She was fully conscious of the risks but decided to climb the mountain anyway.

Joining and Separating.definition: To gain or obtain something through effort or experience.
Joining and Separating.example: He managed to acquire several rare stamps for his collection.

Joining and Separating.definition: The quality of being open to more than one interpretation; unclear meaning.
Joining and Separating.example: The lawyer pointed out the ambiguity in the contract that could lead to disputes.

Joining and Separating.definition: A long, loose outer garment, often worn for ceremonial or formal occasions.
Joining and Separating.example: The professor wore a traditional robe during the graduation ceremony.

Joining and Separating.definition: To reach, accomplish, or achieve a goal or level of success.
Joining and Separating.example: After years of practice, she finally attained mastery in playing the violin.

Joining and Separating.definition: The front part of the brain responsible for decision-making, planning, and social behavior.
Joining and Separating.example: Meditation can help improve the function of the prefrontal cortex.

Joining and Separating.definition: To follow or pursue stealthily or persistently.
Joining and Separating.example: The photographer stalked the rare bird quietly to get a perfect shot.

Joining and Separating.definition: Sound waves with frequencies above the upper limit of human hearing.
Joining and Separating.example: Bats use ultrasonic sound to navigate in complete darkness.

Joining and Separating.definition: A student pursuing a first degree at a college or university.
Joining and Separating.example: She worked as an undergraduate research assistant in the chemistry lab.

Joining and Separating.definition: To concentrate on a particular subject, skill, or area of study.
Joining and Separating.example: He decided to specialize in renewable energy engineering at university.

Joining and Separating.definition: Sound practical judgment that is shared by most people.
Joining and Separating.example: It’s commonsense to carry an umbrella when the forecast predicts rain.

Joining and Separating.definition: Relating to drama, theater, or exaggerated performance.
Joining and Separating.example: Her theatrical gestures made the storytelling more engaging for the children.

Joining and Separating.definition: To gain inspiration or ideas from someone or something.
Joining and Separating.example: The designer drew influence from Japanese minimalism for the new collection.

Joining and Separating.definition: A person who creates and arranges dance movements for performances.
Joining and Separating.example: The choreographer designed a new ballet for the city’s performing arts festival.

Joining and Separating.definition: The friendly and generous reception and entertainment of guests or visitors.
Joining and Separating.example: The hotel is known for its excellent hospitality and attention to detail.

Joining and Separating.definition: The act or system of moving people or goods from one place to another.
Joining and Separating.example: The city has invested heavily in public transit to reduce traffic congestion.

Joining and Separating.definition: Considering real-world conditions rather than theory or ideals.
Joining and Separating.example: Practically speaking, it’s impossible to finish the project in one day.

Joining and Separating.definition: To become or make something gradually thinner or smaller toward one end.
Joining and Separating.example: The path begins to taper as it reaches the forest.

Joining and Separating.definition: A broad range of related ideas, values, or elements.
Joining and Separating.example: The university offers a wide spectrum of engineering programs.

Joining and Separating.definition: Having a smooth rising and falling shape or movement.
Joining and Separating.example: The hikers walked across undulating hills.

Joining and Separating.definition: Shining with a soft, flickering light.
Joining and Separating.example: The lake looked shimmery under the sunset.

Joining and Separating.definition: Paint containing iron compounds that create rich, often metallic colors.
Joining and Separating.example: The sculpture was coated in iron-oxide paint to prevent rust.

Joining and Separating.definition: Completed in a single continuous period of time.
Joining and Separating.example: He finished the entire novel in one sitting.

Joining and Separating.definition: To present or exhibit something in an impressive way.
Joining and Separating.example: The exhibition will showcase local artists.

Joining and Separating.definition: Extremely tall or high in height.
Joining and Separating.example: Towering skyscrapers filled the city skyline.

Joining and Separating.definition: To plan or describe something in detail.
Joining and Separating.example: She mapped out her career goals for the next five years.

Joining and Separating.definition: The process of arranging things into categories based on shared characteristics.
Joining and Separating.example: The scientist developed a new classification system for plants.

Joining and Separating.definition: The level of demand for a particular type of creative or professional output.
Joining and Separating.example: The market for work in digital design has grown rapidly.

Joining and Separating.definition: The system where shares of publicly traded companies are bought and sold.
Joining and Separating.example: Many investors monitor the stock market daily.

Joining and Separating.definition: To slow down or prevent growth or development.
Joining and Separating.example: Lack of sleep can stunt cognitive performance.

Joining and Separating.definition: The state of being unstable or likely to change suddenly.
Joining and Separating.example: Political instability affected the country’s economy.

Joining and Separating.definition: An amount equal to three out of four equal parts.
Joining and Separating.example: Three-quarters of the class passed the exam.

Joining and Separating.definition: A small room or cupboard where food is stored.
Joining and Separating.example: She checked the pantry before going grocery shopping.

Joining and Separating.definition: A main or important element of something, especially food.
Joining and Separating.example: Rice is a staple food in many Asian countries.

Joining and Separating.definition: A freshwater fish known for its snake-like head and aggressive behavior.
Joining and Separating.example: The snakehead has spread rapidly in several rivers.

Joining and Separating.definition: In a way that is suitable or fitting.
Joining and Separating.example: The book is aptly titled 'The Future of Technology.'

Joining and Separating.definition: Having a surface covered with small, hard plates.
Joining and Separating.example: The reptile’s scaly skin protected it from predators.

Joining and Separating.definition: A thin appendage on a fish used for movement and balance in water.
Joining and Separating.example: The shark’s fin cut through the surface of the water.

Joining and Separating.definition: In a way that is not level, balanced, or equal.
Joining and Separating.example: The bricks were unevenly placed.

Joining and Separating.definition: To attach something using small nails or pins.
Joining and Separating.example: He tacked the poster onto the wall.

Joining and Separating.definition: Something added later that was not originally planned.
Joining and Separating.example: The decorations looked like an afterthought.

Joining and Separating.definition: A large number of insects or animals moving together.
Joining and Separating.example: A swarm of bees gathered near the tree.

Joining and Separating.definition: A person who tells a story.
Joining and Separating.example: The narrator describes events from a personal perspective.

Joining and Separating.definition: Relating to measurable extent such as length, width, and height.
Joining and Separating.example: The artist created a dimensional sculpture.

Joining and Separating.definition: A large painting or artwork applied directly to a wall.
Joining and Separating.example: The city commissioned a mural downtown.

Joining and Separating.definition: Work produced by assembling separate pieces into a whole.
Joining and Separating.example: The quilt was created through detailed piecework.

Joining and Separating.definition: A soft, easily carved stone often used in sculpture.
Joining and Separating.example: The artist sculpted the figure from soapstone.

Joining and Separating.definition: A large, thick, flat piece of material.
Joining and Separating.example: The countertop was made from a single slab of marble.

Joining and Separating.definition: An arm or leg of a person or animal.
Joining and Separating.example: The athlete injured his lower limb during the match.

Joining and Separating.definition: A person or thing that corresponds to or has the same function as another.
Joining and Separating.example: The modern device is smaller than its earlier counterpart.
